I'd like to collect the currently known information on the strength of axiom-free Lean and how much classical math we should expect to be provable in it. My own research background is choiceless set theory, so I have a great interest in seeing what formal systems can handle without Choice, even though this isn't a priority for the mathlib community. I predict that down the road, there will be tools which can automatically convert substantial portions of mathlib into axiom-free counterparts, and those into Metamath's iset.mm library.

1) Lean admits axiom-free proofs of a syntactic translation of each theorem of Zermelo set theory (Z). This translation consists of the double negation translation of intuitionistic predicate calculus into classical, followed by quotienting out by extensional equivalence. This was developed by Harvey Friedman to show equiconsistency of IZF and ZF and also applies for translating Z into IZ, which is easily interpreted in CIC, and thus Lean. @Robin Arnez has formalized this translation.

Z is enough to interpret HOL proof systems, and its extension Z+KP is conservative with respect to provable validities of second-order logic (which encode virtually all mainstream mathematics). The main culprits of mainstream theorems to not admit a proof in Z are those which rely essentially on Choice, such as the Banach-Tarski paradox. (Contrary to popular belief, the bulk of classical measure theory can be reasonably carried out without Choice).

The strength of this theory can be pushed a bit further, e.g. Lean should be able to carry out Rathjen's type theoretic interpretation of Z+∃VΨ(ϵΩ+1)Z+\exists V_{\Psi(\epsilon_{\Omega+1})}Z+∃VΨ(ϵΩ+1​)​ (the ordinal is the Bachmann-Howard ordinal, a large computable ordinal).

2) Lean admits axiom-free proofs of every Π20\Pi^0_2Π20​ theorem of ZC+KP verbatim (see Friedman's technique for Π20\Pi^0_2Π20​-conservativity of LEM over nice intuitionistic theories, and my overview of Π41\Pi^1_4Π41​-conservativity of ZC+KP over Z). Π20\Pi^0_2Π20​ sentences are number theoretic propositions of the form "for all n, there exists m such that P(n, m)," where P is a computable property. Famous theorems at or below this complexity include:

  • FLT
  • PNT formulated with effective bounds
  • the weak Goldbach conjecture
  • infinitude of prime pairs of gap ≤246\le 246≤246
  • Baker's theorem restricted to computable reals
  • irrationality of ζ(3)\zeta(3)ζ(3)
  • CFSG
  • the quasi-polynomial time algorithm for Graph Isomorphism
  • PL Poincare conjecture in dimensions ≠4.\neq 4.=4.

Each of their proofs is known or expected to be formalizable in Z (e.g. see Colin McLarty's commentary on how to do this for FLT).

3) Every axiom-free theorem in Lean should be translatable to iset.mm (Metamath's intuitionistic set theory library) appended with a nested sequence of inaccessible sets. The iset.mm logical system is essentially equivalent to IZF set theory.  In Bruno Barras' habilitation thesis, page 135, he bounds the consistency strength of CIC below IZFR\mathrm{IZF}_{\mathrm{R}}IZFR​ + universes. Note that IZFR\mathrm{IZF}_{\mathrm{R}}IZFR​ is a subsystem of IZF (the former uses Replacement, which is weaker than Collection in intuitionistic settings).

Unfortunately, gauging the precise strength of CIC seems difficult. It is conjectured that ZF proves consistency of IZFR\mathrm{IZF}_{\mathrm{R}}IZFR​ (plus universes) but this has been open since Friedman's aforementioned work. Barras also discusses difficulties with achieving universe-by-universe equiconsistency of IZFR\mathrm{IZF}_{\mathrm{R}}IZFR​ vs CIC, in contrast to the success for classical CIC+AC vs ZFC with universes (see Werner's back-and-forth interpretations and @Mario Carneiro's analysis for Lean 3).

Also, until full verification of Lean is achieved, there is the risk that there are outstanding soundness bugs. A proof of False would not translate into Metamath, assuming set theory itself is consistent! But the vast majority of regularly used tactics presumably encode legitimate mathematical reasoning, so there is little reason to doubt that mathlib can be fully translated into set.mm and, with the above techniques formalized, mostly translated into iset.mm.

Huge thank you to @James E Hanson, @Loïc Pujet, @Jeremy Avigad, and Hanul Jeon for many helpful discussions as I compiled this information.

Just to check, when you say "axiom-free" do you mean "without any non-standard axioms" or also "without docs#Classical.choice" or even "without docs#Quot.sound or docs#propext" or worse yet "without the very restricted axiom-like behavior provided by CIC with inductive"?

Eric Wieser said:

Just to check, when you say "axiom-free" do you mean "without any non-standard axioms" or also "without docs#Classical.choice" or even "without docs#Quot.sound or docs#propext" or worse yet "without the very restricted axiom-like behavior provided by CIC with inductive"?

The middle of these. No Classical.choice, propext, or Quot.sound, but keeping the full underlying type theory. This is of course arbitrary accounting; Lean could have just as easily had more or fewer types baked into the kernel, but this gives us a clear base system to discuss.

this is very relevant to my interests! @Elliot Glazer i’m working on a linter tool & tentative graded scale for quantifying the oracle dependence for a given formulation in lean — ie how much classical machinery is actually needed for extraction vs verification.

C0-C5 scale defined here: https://github.com/brittlewis12/witness-budgets/blob/main/witness-budgets.md#11-the-c0c5-spectrum-grading-oracle-dependence

i’ve been exploring this extraction vs verification budget split to assess a few different constructive formulations i’ve worked on to demonstrate their utility. the early stages of this are available here: https://github.com/brittlewis12/witness-budgets

i’d love both feedback and to leverage this tool to map the degree of classical vs extractable formulations (and to hopefully inform & incentivize minimally axiomatic formulations!)

Interesting project! I'm having trouble distinguishing C0 vs C1 in the context of Lean. I'd think that distinction only makes sense for a system like Agda which is based on a predicative type theory. Would you say Lean's kernel is already at C1 level?

The non-linearity of the scale is a bit annoying but I agree these that roughly represent increasingly severe breaches of constructivity.

thanks so much for taking a look! i conceived of the scale somewhat prover-agnostically, but in practice it does seem lean largely falls discontinuously between C0, C3 & C5. the kernel i think you're exactly right about as well, you'd land at least C1 by default.

and your point on the nonlinearity is very fair, it's a somewhat arbitrary level system; perhaps a more coarse-grained approach would be sufficient? i figured up front more degrees of discrimination would go further, but so far those three tiers seem sufficient
